def plot_map_with_projection(projection_type):
    fig = px.choropleth(internet_usage_2019, 
                        locations="country_code",
                        color="individuals_using_the_internet__of_population",
                        hover_name="country_name",
                        color_continuous_scale=px.colors.sequential.Plasma)
    fig.update_layout(title_text = f'Internet usage across the World - 2019',
                     geo = {"projection":{'type':projection_type}})
    fig.show()

projection_type = "natural earth"
# projection_type = "sinusoidal"

# by default,projection type is set to 'equirectangular'

# Checkout the other projection types avaialble here https://plotly.com/python/reference/#layout-geo-projection-type
plot_map_with_projection(projection_type=projection_type)

def plot_map(geo_scope, continent_name):
    fig = px.choropleth(internet_usage_2019, 
                        locations="country_code",
                        color="individuals_using_the_internet__of_population",
                        hover_name="country_name",
                        color_continuous_scale=px.colors.sequential.Plasma)
    fig.update_layout(title_text = f'Internet usage across the {continent_name} Continent - 2019',
                      geo_scope = geo_scope 
                     )
    fig.show()

# Available Geoscopes 
# north america, south america, africa,  asia, europe, usa


plot_map(geo_scope="asia", 
        continent_name='Asia')

source.023de19f: Here the feature "Country Code" refers to a code assigned to each country by a standard called ISO 3166-1. It is widely used so developers across the world have a common way to refer to and access country names in any data. You can learn more about the standard here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_3166-1. The Code feature is also used by plotly to map data to the appropriate locations on the world map
